title: When will the Government of Ontario cease to require people to show proof of COVID-19 vaccination to use indoor areas of restaurants?
preds: There is no evidence that the Canadian government is backing down in its use of vaccine mandates despite protests against them.
the are still head down on this one
I had 100 but the protests are having an impact.   Looks like Sask and Alberta are moving quickly so now a small chance Ontario.   Ford is an invertebrate so unless he is forced, will not move.
Lots of countries seem to be dropping requirements pretty quickly. UK just dropped vax requirement for healthcare workers which surprised me. So It's not impossible
Most of the covid-19 wave is behind, but the number of cases remains high. Seems unlikely sanitary measures will be reduced shortly.

- https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ontario-covid-19-vaccine-passport-plan-january-1.6280166 suggests it won't happen.
- https://toronto.ctvnews.ca/doug-ford-says-ontario-is-not-considering-changing-proof-of-vaccination-requirement-to-three-doses-1.5747906
    - Depicts the government as pretty cautious, so Feb. 12 seems a pretty short time frame for dropping this restriction.
    - Even more so because the (reverted) decision to drop the vaccine passport on Jan 17 was taken more than a month before that
    - On the other hand, the fact that they tried to drop the vaccine passport at all, indicates it's high on their priority list
- https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/covid-19-ontario-jan-20-2022-restrictions-lifting-ford-1.6321329 makes explicit that they're taking a 'cautious approach'
    - Elliot says hospitalizations are expected to decrease around mid of Feb
- https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/covid-19-ontario-jan-19-2022-elliott-moore-update-1.6320029
    - Elliot sees glimmers of hope
- https://www.blogto.com/city/2022/01/doug-ford-announces-plan-lift-ontario-covid-restrictions-timeline/ lays out a plan until mid March to lift restrictions, but doesn't include lifting the vaccine passport So maybe in 1 out of 50 possible futures, the vaccine passport will not be required anymore in restaurants.
Ontario historically has taken COVID more seriously than the US

Ontario currently is in modified lockdown mode.  Indoor dining is restricted until at least January 26, 2022. Even if indoor dining is allowed between January 27, 2022 and  February 12, 2022, proof of vaccination will be necessary to curb covid cases.

It seems like the main way that Ontario would stop enforcing the vaccine mandate in the next two weeks is if a court strikes it down. Does anyone know the status of this lawsuit? https://tnc.news/2021/10/20/justice-centre-to-sue-ontario-government-over-vaccine-passports/
I have found several news articles saying this group was going to sue, but haven't been able to find any further information about it.
I'm not going to 100% purely on the basis of Cromwell's Rule:  https://www.statisticshowto.com/cromwells-rule/
With the Omikron variant, the world is boostering the population. That makes it more likely that a proof is important.

Before 11/19 evidently 0% by now
Between 11/19-12/31 I would it give it a 0% also. On Onatio.ca I found this: "Beginning January 4, 2022, Ontarians will be required to use their enhanced vaccine certificate with official QR code. Vaccine receipts without a QR code will no longer be accepted as valid proof of vaccination" and there has been no changes on indoor activities that require a valid vaccination certification
Before  02/11 I would give it a ~0% Given the Omnicron development and the European experience with new spikes of infection given the winter time. I will give it 1% just for the fact that it is not totally out of question

Over 1800 cases reported in Ontario today, and numbers are rising.
Toronto extended it's mask mandate until April.
Ford Gov't allows everyone over 18 to book booster as of Monday Dec 20th.
Looks like numbers will increase before they decrease, and I can't see lifting the vaccine passport mandate until numbers are in the low 100's - maybe not until next summer.
Masks and proof of vaccination could become cultural norms for the forseeable future.
No brainer.  Path of least political resistance is to keep the restrictions.

I am getting increasingly confident of a post-Feb 12 relaxing of rules given the recent developments: https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-to-extend-covid-19-vaccine-passport-system-no-plans-to-shut/ -- "Ontario intends to keep its COVID-19 vaccine passport program in place later than Jan. 17 and will require all certificates to include a digital QR code, part of new measures the government plans to announce on Friday that also have a stricter process for verifying medical exemptions, sources say." // "But Ms. Elliott stopped short earlier this week of saying the Jan. 17 date was off the table."
Ford gov't announced a halt to any 'relaxing' of public health measures - which were planned for Jan 1, 2022.
If it happens, it will not be until the holidays are over but not immediately after because then it appears as though politicians are attacking holidays, families, and Jesus.
The official announcement by the Ontarian government mentions that they are looking at normalcy and re-opening post March 2022.

Given the information outlined here: https://news.ontario.ca/en/release/1001027/ontario-releases-plan-to-safely-reopen-ontario-and-manage-covid-19-for-the-long-term -- that we will lift measures by March 2022, I suspect that the base case is for measures to be lifted by March 2022, which is beyond Feb 12. In order for me to give any probability to the earlier dates, I'd have to see significant evidence of improving case counts, reduced threat of variants, and reduced transmission. Given the recent rise of the Omicron variant, my logic dictates that we are more likely to push past March 2022 rather than accelerate the lifting of restrictions. Further, my experience as a current resident of Ontario also informs this view (although that is a somewhat biased view, I do feel I have a good pulse on political sentiment here). I did allocate 2% to between Jan 1nad Feb 11 as there are no guarentees in any case and maybe something substantial changes in the next 60 days.
Omicron and VOC have put world governments back on edge. Going for later date
The crowd likely has this one.  Everything is ticking along fine with current restrictions so there's little to no incentive to remove the requirement sooner than necessary
Current regulatory framework is allowing businesses to start operating again, and this framework will be a minimum  standard going forward with new variants
Everything seems to be moving to late March 2022 at the earliest.

Curbing my enthusiasm: there's a substantial chance that the government could delegate the responsibility to local officials or even local restaurants to make that decision themselves. Europe is seeing protests in even the most peaceful countries. Canada may notice this and decide if they want to go down this route too, or risk it at all. It also sounds Canadian to have restrictions eased should cases remain steady or cases decline as a Christmas "miracle" gift to its citizens. But that may be a stretch. Starting the new year fresh is also a viable consideration, as shifts in laws tend to happen after the holidays. However, I think this resolving yes in any of the first 3 bins is still overall an unlikely scenario given that vaccination cards and proof of vaccination seems to be the new norm.

Ontario science table head says "Chance of vaccine mandates ending in January 'next to zero'" (https://ottawa.ctvnews.ca/chance-of-vaccine-mandates-ending-in-january-next-to-zero-ontario-science-table-head-says-1.5679932). Of cause then there would be only 12 days left... ;-) I give "Between 1 January 2022 and 11 February 2022" a chance of 5%.
There is likely to be some resurgence of cases during the winter months delaying return to normality.

Current government messaging (as of end of October): "Proof-of-vaccination requirements will also start to be lifted early next year — as long as trends don’t become concerning — starting with restaurants, bars, gyms and casinos in January."
Children will begin vaccinations in the next few weeks - so infections should slowly go down.
Christmas/new years gatherings may introduce a wave of infections. 
Provincial election is June 3, 2022.
Ontario is on a good trajectory wrt to covid cases. I think the Ford gov't will want to lift restrictions as soon as possible, however will not want to risk another surge before election time - hence I put more probability with a post Feb 12. lifting of measures - even if our cases are low in Jan.
Govt watching the cases from christmas holiday and school re-openings. Olympics starting in February,
Ontario has announced timeframes for dropping COVID restrictions.
They have said Jan 17th, but the recent uptick does not bode well for numbers, and I think it will have to be pushed into late winter / spring, as people get back outdoors and cases come down.
Post holiday season, and pre election activities will start to be more intense for the Conservatives.
Almost no chance of happening pre-Christmas. If the holidays go well and vaccinations are high it could be considered in the new year
Winter wave might strike fast and dissipate quickly before February, but highly unlikely the authorities immediately ease up as soon as the wave is over.

With flu season and Christmas approaching, Ontario seems comfortable with a cautious and defensive position on mask wearing and vaccinations.
Both of these measures have been instrumental in keeping Ontario Covid infections, hospitalities and fatalities all (comparatively) low.
In comparison to the UK, where there is a looser application of defensive measures, Canadians in general seem prepared to continue with methods that have proven effective at home and abroad.
General election isn't until mid-2022; expect this issue to grow in importance in the weeks and months leading up to the election.

It seems to me that holiday season and the winter season will be a large factor in the reluctance to go back to no COVID screening. Whether or not this will be the new normal is a more uncertain question.

72% are fully vaccinated which is still well off of herd immunity. With drugs like molnavirapir on the horizon that's likely to take the pressure off but I'd be very surprised if its eased prior to the holiday season, and even that drug is unlikely to be available in significant quantities in the near future (I'm not actually sure when it will be available in Canada even after FDA approval. Canada typically lags the US on drug approvals). There really isn't any reason to remove the restriction as it's basically become the new normal where it's been implemented. I've put some chance in the earlier categories as a hedge but really don't believe it will be lifted until some time next summer.
